p.seg: ZZJS 379 reads 獊 for 傖 and X for
Wandering through the Great Void,
and roaming in the court of illusion and confusion.
Even greedy people,
and impetuous scholars,
if they but momentarily grasp its remaining fragrance,
taste its overflowing stream,
and faintly perceive its sounds and shadows, would still be sufficiently broadened to have a forget-the-body, self-satisfied feeling.
How much more so, those who explore its profound emotions and contemplate eternity!
Thus, they may extend into vast and clear distances, depart from the dust of the world,
and return to the ultimate darkness.
Preface to the Commentary on the True Scripture of Nanhua
Written by Cheng Xuanying, Dharma Master of Xihua of the Tang Dynasty.
Now, Zhuangzi is that which extends the deep roots of morality and virtue,
narrates the subtle purpose of profound mystery,
expresses the tranquility of non-action,
elucidates the profound obscurity of solitary transformation,
restrains and silences the nine schools,
and encompasses the hundred masters.
Truly, it is the ultimate teaching within the realm,
and in reality, the subtle words beyond form.
The man's surname was Zhuang, his given name Zhou,
his courtesy name Zixiu.
He was born in the Meng County of Suiyang in the State of Song.
His teacher was Lord Sangsang,
and he received the title of Immortal Nanhua.
He lived at the beginning of the Warring States period,
towards the end of the declining Zhou Dynasty.
Lamenting the shallowness of the lives of the people,
and grieving the decay of morality and virtue,
he was filled with indignation and resolved,
and thereupon authored this treatise.
Its words are grand and broad,
its purpose is deep and far-reaching,
not to be heard by inferior scholars.
how could shallow understanding fathom it!
"Zi" as spoken of here,
is an esteemed appellation for those of virtue.
In ancient times, teachers were called "Zi,"
also "Zi" is said to be the name of a book.
It is not only a general name for these three chapters,
but also a common title for the various schools of thought.
"Nei Pian" as spoken of here,
establishes its name by taking the "inner" as the foundation for dealing with the "outer,"
"Pian" signifies the meaning of arranged tablets.
In ancient times, green bamboo was scraped to make tablets,
and leather was used for binding.
Arranged tablets become a "Pian,"
just as today, joined paper becomes a scroll.
Therefore, Yuan Kai said:
"Important matters are recorded on bamboo slips,
minor matters are merely written on tablets."
"Inner" then, discusses fundamental principles,
"Outer" narrates historical events.
Although events are clearly evident,
they cannot be understood without principles;
although principles are subtle and profound,
Affairs that are not true are not revealed.
Desiring to first clarify the wondrous principles,
therefore, the Inner Chapters are marked out in front.
The Inner Chapters contain profound principles,
therefore, separate titles are established for each outside the text.
Guo Xiang still provided annotations directly under the title,
such as "Free and Easy Wandering" and "Making All Things Equal."
From the Outer Chapters onward,
the first two characters of the chapter are taken as the title,
such as "Webbed Toes" and "Horses' Hooves."
Regarding what is said about "Free and Easy Wandering,"
interpretations differ from ancient to modern times.
Now, broadly outlining the essential principles,
I will briefly offer three interpretations.
These three interpretations are:
First,
Gu Tongbai said:
"'Xiao' means to dissipate.
'Yao' means distant.
Dissipating completely the burdens of purposeful action,
seeing distantly the principles of non-action.
Wandering with this,
therefore it is called 'Free and Easy Wandering.'"
Second,
Zhi Daolin said:
"Engaging with things without being possessed by them,
therefore, one wanders freely without relying on oneself;
responding subtly without haste, yet with speed,
therefore, one wanders distantly without anything not being done.
Wandering the world with this,
therefore it is called 'Free and Easy Wandering.'"
Third,
Mu Ye said:
"'Free and Easy Wandering' is essentially a name for unrestrained, self-possessed contentment."
The Kun's size,
is unknown how many thousands of miles it is.
Shu [Commentary]:
"Ming" means the sea;
it is named "Ming" taking its vast and boundless [appearance].
The Eastern Sage's "Records of the Ten Continents" says:
"In the Ming Sea, without wind, there are hundred-zhang waves."
"Within the great sea,
there is this great fish."
It intends to clarify that the nature of things is natural, therefore, it is marked as the beginning of the chapter.
The "Records from the Mystic Center" says:
"In the East, there is a great fish.
One who travels by foot spends one day passing its head,
and seven days passing its tail.
When it gives birth for three days,
the green sea turns red because of it.
From this, one knows that great things are born in great places.
Is it only limited to the Northern Ming?"
It transforms into a bird,
its name is Peng.
Note:
The reality of the Peng and the Kun,
is something I do not fully understand.
The main idea of Zhuangzi,
lies in unfettered wandering and freedom,
in non-action and self-attainment.
Therefore, he exaggerates both the extremely small and extremely large
in order to clarify the suitability of one's nature.
So as to clarify the suitability of one's natural disposition.
An enlightened person
should grasp the ultimate point of convergence,
and disregard the means by which it is conveyed;
it is not necessary to meticulously explain everything.
As long as it does not detract from the grand
intent, all can be glossed over.
Commentary:
The four seasons rush by like the wind,
the three luminaries flash like lightning;
therefore, they bear mountains and abandon the old,
lift boats from valleys and hasten toward the new.
Thus, the transformation of fish into birds
is intended to illuminate the great principle of change.
The back of the Peng
is not known to be how many thousands of miles.
When it rages and flies,
its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky.
Commentary:
Speaking of the fish in terms of its size
is to indicate that its head and tail are difficult to know;
speaking of the bird in terms of its back
also shows that its length and shortness are unfathomable.
Therefore, the following text says that there is no one who knows its length.
Stirring up its wings in anger,
shaking its feathered coat with swiftness,
already intending to ride the wind,
about to strike the water.
Thereupon, it severs the clouds,
carries the blue sky on its back,
soaring and gliding,
reaching and touching the celestial [regions],
[casting] shadows [like] hanging curtains,
as if traveling clouds were descending from the edge of the sky.
This bird,
when the ocean currents move, it will migrate to the Southern Ocean.
The Southern Ocean
is the Pool of Heaven.
Note:
If it were not the vast ocean, it would be insufficient to carry its body;
if it were not ninety thousand miles, it would be insufficient to bear its wings.
Is this because it likes strangeness?
It is simply that a large creature must necessarily originate in a large place,
and a large place must also necessarily give rise to this large creature.
The principle is naturally so.
There is no need to worry about its loss;
then why bother to concern yourself with it?
Commentary:
"Yun" (運) means to turn, to revolve.
"Shi" (是) means to point out, to indicate.
Thus, this Peng bird, its form is weighty and large.
If it did not revolve in the sea,
it would have no way to achieve high ascension.
All are compelled, not willing.
It is not willingly so.
Furthermore, once its form has changed,
Emotions also change accordingly.
In the past, I was a fish,
swimming in the North Sea;
now I am a bird,
soaring in the South Sea.
Although rising and sinking differ in nature,
carefree wandering is the same.
It is also like death and life, gathering and scattering,
one adapts to what one encounters.
Through thousands of changes and transformations,
nothing has ever not been me,
this is why I transform from a fish into a bird.
As for going from north to south,
a bird is a creature that transcends the void,
south is the region of enlightenment;
a fish is a creature that is mired and drowning,
north is a place of darkness;
it is intended to express turning towards the light and turning one's back on darkness,
abandoning stagnation and seeking advancement,
therefore, the north and south, bird and fish, are mentioned to show the path of the Dao.
As for the great sea and vast rivers,
they are originally the work of creation,
not made by humans,
therefore, it is called the "heavenly pool."
The "Qi Xie"
is a record of strange things.
The "Xie" says:
When the Peng bird migrates to the South Sea,
Water strikes for three thousand li;
soaring upwards on a whirlwind, it ascends ninety thousand li.
Commentary:
Indeed, if wings are large, they are difficult to lift.
Therefore, it can only ascend after gathering on a whirlwind.
Ninety thousand li is enough to overcome itself.
Since it has such wings,
how could it suddenly rise
and descend after only a few ren?
All of this is unavoidable;
it is not something it enjoys.
It goes to rest in the sixth month.
Commentary:
The large bird travels for half a year to reach the celestial pool and rest;
the small bird flies for half a morning,
stopping at the elm and the fang trees.
The difference lies in their ability,
but their suitability to their nature is the same.
Commentary:
The surname is Qi, the given name is Xie;
this is a person's name,
and it also refers to the name of a book.
The state of Qi possesses this book of uncouth stories.
"Zhi" means "record".
"Ji" means "strike".
"Tuan" means "fight".
"Fuyao" means "whirlwind".
The book written by Qi Xie
He often recorded strange and unusual events.
Zhuangzi cited these as evidence
to demonstrate that what he said was not false.
The Peng bird, about to journey to the Southern Ocean,
cannot simply rise up suddenly.
Therefore, it lifts and strikes with both wings,
stirring and shaking the three thousand (li),
staggering along,
before it can leave the water.
Then, circling and turning,
building anger and hovering,
the winds assisting it,
shaking and rising upwards,
a journey passing through ninety thousand (li),
a time span of half a year,
leisurely and content, full of ambition,
only then does it speak of resting.
Just enough is enough,
why begrudge the sentiment!
The wild horses also,
and the dust,
are creatures blown by each other's breath.
Note:
All these are what the Peng relies on to fly.
The wild horses are
wandering vapors.
Commentary:
The Erya states:
Beyond the town is called the "suburb" (郊);
beyond the suburb is called the "pasture" (牧);
beyond the pasture is called the "wilderness" (野).
This speaks of the time of youth,
when the Yang energy is stirred,
and gazing distantly into the marshes and wetlands,
it is like galloping horses,
therefore it is called "wilderness horses" (野馬).
Raised dust is called "dust" (塵);
the finest dust is called "motes" (埃).
Between Heaven and Earth,
the breath of living things mutually stirs and moves,
in order to lift up the Peng bird.
The four kinds of beings,
in a mixed and jumbled state,
the myriad types are uneven,
their forms and natures are different,
and their resources and needs should be different.
Therefore, the Peng bird flaps its wings that hang down from Heaven,
relying on the wind to roam freely;
the cicada stretches its wings to dart upwards,
and is content with the elm and the sappanwood tree.
All of these act according to their nature,
endowed by the Creator,
without affection for distance or nearness,
how could they be concerned with pride or conceit!
One who embodies this趣 (interest/tendency), how can one talk of boasting or ambition?!
The blueness of the sky,
Is that its true color?
Is it distant and without a point of ultimate arrival?
When it looks down,
is it simply like this?
Note:
Now when we observe the azure sky,
we ultimately do not know if that is truly the sky's true color?
Or if the sky is far and without limit?
The Peng, from above, looking at the earth,
is also like a person from here looking at the sky.
Then it stops and plans to go south,
saying the quail does not know the distance of the journey,
(but its) pace is enough to carry itself and depart.
Commentary:
Looking up at the round sky,
it is extremely distant,
the blue sky is high and far,
calculations are without end.
The azure is vast and indistinct,
how could that be the sky's true color?
However, the Peng is in the middle of the sky,
humans reside on the lower earth,
and the quail's looking down
is no different than humans' looking up.
Since humans do not distinguish the sky's true color,
how could the Peng know the earth's distance?
Carrying itself and being satisfied,
it goes to the Southern Sea.
The measure of the Peng's flight,
stops right there.
Furthermore, if the accumulation of water is not deep,
then it will not have the strength to carry a large boat.
If you spill a cup of water on a low-lying part of the hall,
then a blade of grass can be its boat.
But if you place a cup on it, it will stick,
because the water is shallow and the boat is large.
Note:
All of this explains why the Peng flies so high:
its wings are large, that's why.
If the substance is small, then what it relies on doesn't need to be large.
If the substance is large, then what it uses cannot be small.
Therefore, principle has its ultimate division,
and things have their fixed limit.
Each is sufficient to fulfill its purpose,
and their effectiveness is the same.
If one loses sight of the master of forgetting life
and seeks life outside of what is most appropriate,
the effort will not be effective,
and the action will not match the expectation.
Then, even if one rides the wings of heaven, one cannot avoid exhaustion,
and even the decisive flight cannot avoid difficulty!
Commentary:
"Qie" is a particle used for introducing a topic,
it is a word for brief consideration.
"Fu" is an opening particle, placed at the beginning of a statement.
"Ji" means to accumulate.
"Hou" means deep.
"Bei" is a small vessel.
"Ao" means a depression,
referring to a low-lying place in the hall's courtyard.
"Jie" is grass.
"Jiao" means to stick.
